data.title: atom-mac.zip is pretty big
data.body:
I downloaded atom-mac.zip from atom.io and saw that it was 104MB. I was surprised that it was so big, so I looked at what files are taking up the most space inside the zip archive:

```
$ unzip -vl atom-mac.zip | perl -ne 'my @fields = split " ", $_, 8; print $fields[2], " ", $fields[7], "\n";' | sort -rn | head -n 30
25033212 Atom.app/Contents/Frameworks/Atom Framework.framework/Versions/A/Libraries/libchromiumcontent.dylib
1908336 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/biscotto/node_modules/connect/node_modules/multiparty/test/fixture/multi_video.upload
1572596 Atom.app/Contents/Frameworks/Atom Framework.framework/Versions/A/Atom Framework
1468459 Atom.app/Contents/Frameworks/Atom Framework.framework/Versions/A/Resources/content_shell.pak
1422369 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/scandal/node_modules/git-utils/build/Release/git2.a
1421150 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/git-utils/build/Release/git2.a
1205803 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/objects.json
1205803 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/release-notes/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/objects.json
1205803 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/markdown-preview/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/objects.json
933750 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/people.json
933750 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/release-notes/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/people.json
933750 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/markdown-preview/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/people.json
829946 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/jasmine-tagged/node_modules/jasmine-node/node_modules/jasmine-reporters/ext/js.jar
829946 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/jasmine-node/node_modules/jasmine-reporters/ext/js.jar
829946 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/jasmine-focused/node_modules/jasmine-node/node_modules/jasmine-reporters/ext/js.jar
766508 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/biscotto/node_modules/connect/node_modules/multiparty/test/fixture/http/encoding/pf1y5.png.http
765995 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/biscotto/node_modules/connect/node_modules/multiparty/test/fixture/file/pf1y5.png
656818 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/symbols.json
656818 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/release-notes/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/symbols.json
656818 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/markdown-preview/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/symbols.json
627534 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/nature.json
627534 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/release-notes/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/nature.json
627534 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/markdown-preview/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/nature.json
599596 Atom.app/Contents/_CodeSignature/CodeResources
501425 Atom.app/Contents/Frameworks/Atom Framework.framework/Versions/A/Libraries/ffmpegsumo.so
464640 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/settings-view/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/places.json
464640 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/release-notes/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/places.json
464640 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/markdown-preview/node_modules/roaster/node_modules/emoji-images/json/places.json
330534 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/git-utils/build/Release/git.node
330431 Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/scandal/node_modules/git-utils/build/Release/git.node
```

A few things I noticed:
- libchromiumcontent is huge. No surprise there.
- multiparty's test fixtures are pretty big, especially multi_video.upload (1.9MB compressed all by itself!). Maybe they can be omitted?
- There are two copies of `git2.a`, each about 1.4MB compressed. They aren't the exact same size, but maybe there's a way to get away with just one?
- Looks like the `settings-view`, `release-notes`, and `markdown-preview` packages all include their own copy of `emoji-images`, which has lots of biggish files in it. Can they all share one copy somehow?

data.title: Properly exit when render process crashes if exitWhenDone option is true
data.body:
This PR fixes two problems:
- When a render process crash occured in specs, we were trying to exit via an undefined atom global and throwing a confusing exception in the process.
- We probably don't want to exit the application unless we're running _headless_ specs, so I've switched this to check the ::exitWhenDone setting.

data.title: Split selection into lines
data.body:
Take a multi-line selection and break it apart to create multiple single line selections covering the same area.

Refs #1365

data.title: Upgrade to space pen 3
data.body:
Has some performance upgrades that make view creation faster

See atom/space-pen#21 for details.

The recent polish for this feedback feature is really nice. <3

data.title: Clean up TextBuffer
data.body:
Since I've introduced the [text-buffer](https://github.com/atom/text-buffer) npm, I took the opportunity to to take another pass at documenting TextBuffer and cleaning up its API a bit. I've improved the documentation of text-related methods and moved them out of Atom into the npm. I've also tuned some of the methods to minimize allocations by eliminating options hashes, removing intermediate array representations of points and ranges, normalizing line endings without using replace, etc.
### Proposed API changes

The old methods are all still present as deprecated shims for now.
- `::change` -> `::setTextInRange`

I think it would be nice to move all the text-related methods into the npm and only deal with the backing of the file system here.

data.title: Markers stick around on folding
data.body:
- fold some code
- search for something that has a bunch of results (`e` or something)
- unfold code that has results after it
- note that the unfolded code's results markers are still there.

![screen shot 2014-01-06 at 4 13 15 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/69169/1855500/9bc82a58-7730-11e3-8ee9-e65180a44f72.png)

This might have something to do with fnr's handling of markers, but seems core related.

This is on a fresh build of a non-telepath core.

data.title: Add error event to atom global
data.body: This lets packages listen for unhandled exceptions. The only reason I made it a pull request was in case there are going to be issues with Atom emitting events.

data.title: Make Directory::getEntries asynchronous
data.body:
Renames `getEntries` to `getEntriesSync`.

This will enable adding a little :racehorse: to the tree view.

Also updates `getRealPath` to `getRealPathSync` for consistency since under the hood it uses `fs.realpathSync`.

data.title: Commands to create multiple cursors, multiple selections
data.body:
It’s great that Atom supports multiple cursors, but unless I’m mistaken, the only way to really _get_ multiple cursors happening is to manually `cmd` + click where you want new cursors. A few of the things I miss about Sublime Text are:
- Being able to add an additional cursor to the line above/below the current one.

![subl-add-cursors](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/1850161/7edcc160-76c7-11e3-9615-6625e5aaebc5.gif)
- Being able to select multiple lines, and then split the selection into multiple lines.

![subl-split-lines](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/1850164/9c292cd6-76c7-11e3-86c9-262964ef8e36.gif)
- Being able to quickly add next/all search results in a file as additional selections.

![subl-quick-next](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/1850291/8a2046dc-76cc-11e3-9b79-50e0b298f2ed.gif)

I’d :heart: it if similar shortcuts could be added to Atom’s multiple caret/selection repertoire.

See also: http://www.sublimetext.com/docs/2/multiple_selection_with_the_keyboard.html

data.title: Single clicking a directory expands the tree entry
data.body: Clicking on a directory in the file listing expands or collapses the entry. This makes it tough to select a directory, then press `a` to add a new file to the directory. Clicking the arrow or double-clicking the text should expand the entry. Single clicking the text should just select the directory. This would match the OS X Finder behavior too.

data.title: Add prepend/append methods to WorkspaceView
data.body: This fixes the problem of Tool Panels appending themselves below the status bar. It also adds other convenience methods so to make adding Tool Panels to the top/left/right more understandable (and also let's us get away with leaving the horizontal and vertical divs undocumented)

data.title: Can’t Rename a file by only changing the case of the filename
data.body:
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a file named `AAAA`.
2. Right click in the file browser and select Rename.
3. Rename the file to `aaaa`.
### Expected Results

The file should rename to the chosen name.
### Actual Results

An error is given that the file already exists and to try another path.

data.title: If I right-click on an item in Atom that has a context menu (like a file in the tree view) I can
data.body:
If I right-click on an item in Atom that has a context menu (like a file in the tree view) I can interact with the menu, but selecting a menu option (like Rename) doesn't do anything.

data.title: Cj keybinding fixes
data.body:
This fixes a few keybinding issues people have opened. 

One change that might be annoying is `ctrl-a` now triggers `editor:move-to-beginning-of-line` instead of `editor:move-to-first-character-of-line`. But this matches the default OS X keybinding behavior.

data.title: Remove Telepath from core
data.body:
Summary of changes

Having decided via painful experience that putting telepath into core was a bad idea, this PR removes it. I've replaced non-replication oriented features that were previously handled by telepath with smaller npm packages.
- **[text-buffer](https://github.com/atom/text-buffer)** This handles the storage of text and markers that was previously dealt with in telepath strings. It also implements the undo system for buffers.
- **[theorist](https://github.com/atom/theorist)** This provides a `Model` superclass that will provide the reactive features that proved to be valuable from Telepath models. Model subclasses allow you to subscribe to $-prefixed reactive behaviors for any property, declare derived reactive properties with `.behavior`, and will soon include facilities for defining reactive collections with relational operators. It took me a couple tries to find a good name, so if you see references to `reactionary` or `atomic-model` in commits, that's this library.
- **[serializable](https://github.com/atom/serializable)** This provides a convenient mixin for implementing `::serialize` and `.deserialize`. It's completely optional, meaning anyone can implement those methods on their own, but it removes a lot of the boilerplate. I think this package should also provide the deserializer manager and eventually incorporate support for migrations.

**What's the plan for replication going forward?**

I think I had it exactly backwards. Instead of wrapping a replication layer with the application's model, we should wrap the application's model with a replication layer. I think Telepath should be transformed into an unobtrusive wrapper library that can wrap any JavaScript object graph and automagically replicate it to another site. I think we can pull off something seamless by combining the new ES6 `Object.observe` API, ES5 `WeakMap`s, and everything I learned implementing references in the last attempt. I'd like something like this to be possible:

``` coffee
{Replicant} = require 'telepath'

# start with a plain old javascript object
atomA = new Atom(mode: 'editor') 

# build a replicant wrapper based on this object
replicantA = new Replicant(atomA) 

# replicate it (this is for tests, across the wire we'd serialize)
replicantB = replicantA.replicate(siteId: 2) 

 # extract a fresh plain-old object from the replica
atomB = replicantB.root
```

The end user never needs to interact with telepath. They just modify properties on the plain objects and telepath picks up their changes and replicates them transparently. This keeps telepath out of the critical path for the single-user case because it's bolted on from the outside only when needed. It also means we can expand the scope of replication in an ad-hoc fashion, starting with a single buffer and moving outward.

Finer-grained control of what properties are replicated is still possible on a per-object and per-class basis. Here's a sketch of what I'm thinking:

``` coffee
# exclude instances of an entire class from being replicated
replicant.disable(TreeView)

# only replicate particular properties for instances of a certain class
replicant.enable(Pane, 'items')

# dynamically enable / disable replication for certain instances
replicant.enable(focusManager)
```

Again, the key is we can start small and only pay for what we use.

data.title: Update atom-shell to v0.8.x
data.body:
- [ ] Make native modules compile on Windows
- [x] Make native modules compile on Mac
- [x] Fix sandbox of coffee script
- [x] Web view is blank on the first run
- [ ] The `CFBundleVersion` field of `Info.plist` is sometimes empty
- [x] Make specs pass
- [x] Initial size is sometimes `{width: 0, height: 0}`
- [x] Crash caused by setTimeout in third party native modules (https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/153)
- [x] process.nextTick does not work sometimes (https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/pull/154)
- [x] Task can not receive messages from child process sometimes (https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/156)
- [x] FATAL ERROR: v8::HandleScope::CreateHandle() Cannot create a handle without a HandleScope (https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/commit/931182b677e81c4bf6922193478af861193d952c)
